summary: herbal formula was first described in “Dan Xi Xin Fa” by Zhu Danxi. YPFS exerts antiviral effects including influenza virus, human respiratory syncytial virus, and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) virus [1]–[5], as well as curative effects in inflammation-associated diseases. YPFS suppressed pro-inflammatory cytokines in a lipopolysaccharide-induced chronic inflammation model. YPFS stimulated the production of immunoglobulin after antigens were directly injected into the body. YPFS suppressed immunoglobulin production when external antigens were infused in the nasal mucus. a reduced expression of IALP in IBD patients was shown to be closely correlated with gut inflammation [21], [22]. in TCM clinics today, YPFS is widely used in treating IBD; however, the underlying mechanism of YPFS remains poorly understood. we chose 2 specific cellular models: macrophages and enterocytes. the maximum dose of all extracts could be at 3 mg/mL in the following experiments.
